thread.name: AU WG joining us for an afternoon at F2F in Bristol?

sent.#text: Wendy states that they are moving forward with a face to face meeting in Bristol, England on Oct 5-6.
The Authoring tool group will join them to discuss revisions to the WCAG on the 6th.
She asks the group if they like to discuss the draft they have now and asks if they want to work on a draft for 2 full days.
William responds that it is mandatory to discuss the draft to avoid conflicts and oversights.
He thinks it'll take greater than 2 days to work on the draft. He is looking forward to the meeting in Bristol.
Jonathan asks he is attending the venue, what the agenda is and if it would be useful if he attended with a presentation.
Charles responds and says it suits him to meet and discuss the draft.
Wendy answers all of Jonathan's questions: registration has not started, there is no agenda yet, and yes it would be worthwhile if Jonathan attended with a presentation.
Lisa, who is new to the group, asks for information regarding the conference so she may attend.
Jonathan thanks Wendy for her response and outlines some of his plans for the conference.
This email is a compilation of exchanges from people who wish to have a face-to-face meeting in Bristol, England, on the 5th or 6th of October.
Authoring Tool Working group may join the meeting to discuss the revision of WCAG on the afternoon of the 6th.
William believe that the states of the draft require need to be discussed.
He believes that it will take more time to work on the draft and that a meeting involving U will constitute "working on the draft".
Jonathan wants to find out who will be attending and the agenda, if possible.
Charles confirmed about the details for the meeting and that.
Ilsa is new so she asks for more directions about the meeting.
The e-mails below contain discussions regarding a face2face meeting in Bristol, England on October 5th and 6th

Wendy, which is the web accessibility initiative for the world wide web consortium suggested that they could use the meeting opportunity to discuss the current state of the draft with another working group.
Although the meeting will require them two full days to work on the draft of the meeting
The core WCAG members will be attending the meetings on Oct. 5th and 6th
as well, there will be someone with learning difficulties to demonstrate problems regarding web accessibility
Steven mentions that screen-reading, text-to-speech software appears to have trouble with common neologisms such as "homepage".
He wonders whether there is mention of this difficulty in the accessibility guidelines.
There are, but they may not be sufficient.
Emails continue to discuss the problems with text-to-speech and how they could be addressed.
Steven says that when using a screen reader, some joined words like homepage are not recognized.
He has not found any reference to this in the guidelines.
Charles advises Steven to use the simplest language possible.
However, homepage really should be a working term.
Text to speech is an inexacct science though, even experts can disagree.
Al advises to hyphenate compounds if they are not old and well-established words.
Some screen readers will successfully divide compounds, but not all.
He says to use a small word list and handle words outside the list as special.
Jonathan says that common dictionary words are read easily.
However, names of places and people are not.
He says it would be good if there was something that could address this problem.
Charles says this could be done using speech synthesis markup language.
Or if Audio CSS allowed for an equivalent to SSML's say-as property, that would be closer as well.
Al says that SSML does provide the WCAG piece.
But who accesses the dictionary?
Al says that Jonathan is suggesting uploading pronunciation repairs to the community.
Steven observes that screen readers often make mistakes with compound words and have not found any reference to this problem in the guidelines and wonders if he had missed them.

Charles suggests a way around the problem is to use clear and simple language but also notes that speech language software needs to improve and deal with new terms that arise in language and different pronunciation.
Al responds to Steven's question that the guidelines are not obvious in the least and recommends hyphenating words when in doubt.
He further comments on how some screen readers can separate compound words using small word lists.
Jonathan raises the issue of pronouncing proper names correctly.
To him readers do a good job at reading dictionary terms but not proper names and he suggests a program offer alternate pronunciations to share with a public database.
Charles responds that some programs can already do what Jonathan is suggesting and suggests making smarter speech synthesizers.

Al comments that Charles may have missed the point on Jonathan's comments and clarifies that main emphasis is on sharing on a public database, but there are some technical complications to that strategy.

The email dialogue opens with Paul sending a message to the mailing list about a case where a wheelchair user is taking London Stanstead Airport and Ryan Air to court for charging them to use a chair and lift to get into and out of an airplane.
Jon indicates that airlines are usually charged by the airport for use of those facilities but that the air service providers rarely pass this charge onto the customer.
Charles and Scarlett wonder how this news is relevant to internet accessibility.
Charles then considers that a court decision on accessibility regarding payment for legally required improvements could have impacts on web accessibility.
Paul mentions a case where a wheelchair user is suing an airport and airline for being charged $18 to get his wheelchair on the plane.
Paul says the case should be open and shut, and they are only contesting it because it sets a precedent to service all disabled travellers worldwide.
Jon says that the airports charge the airlines to use the lifts.
Most airlines don't pass this charge on to the consumer, whereas Ryan Air does.
Charles asks what the relevance to Web Accessibility is.
Paul says that Monarch also charges the consumer.
Scarlett says this unrelated to web accessibility.
She requests it to be taken up off the list.
Jon admits it is off-topic.
He apologizes.
Paul admits it is not relevant.
He asks for forgiveness.
Charles says forgiveness is granted.
he also says that the case has interesting legal ramifications.
However, this is off-topic and should be discussed elsewhere.
Bob says that in the USA it is forbidden for the cost to be passed to the consumer.
The thread begins by discussing a legal case involving airlines and accessibility.
A few emails carry on the discussion, talking about legal responsibilities and costs.
However, many believe the discussion is off topic.
Chuck sends out an email to the list reminding the recipients of a conference call later that day.
Robert suggests some topics that can be discussed during the call.
Jonathan makes a request that the phone number and time of the call be included in the reminder email, while Gregory asks for the reminder email to be sent the day before the meeting.
Jon brings to attention the policy that meeting announcements, including an agenda, are to be posted at least twenty-four hours in advance of the meeting.
Chuck says that there is a WCAG conference call today, despite it being Thanksgiving.
The subject of discussion is Wendy's draft charter.
He says attendance is optional for the Americans.
Robert asks if anyone has comments on the Macromedia case study.
He also wishes to modify the 50 State map.
He asks if anyone has comments on his products.
Jonathan asks for the phone number and time to be included in communications.
He has trouble being available due to teaching duties.
Gregory asks, in addition to Jonathan's requests, for email reminders to be sent out the day before the meeting.
Jonathan agrees with Gregory.
Jon says it is WAI and probably W3c policy to post meeting announcements 24 hours beforehand.
He has tried to adhere to this policy.
Jonathan says thanks.
The main topic is a reminder of a conference call to be held on the Thanksgiving holiday
The topic for the call is Wendy's draft charter
Attendance at the meeting is optional.
A request to always include telephone numbers and times of these conference calls as well as a reminder email prior to meeting is made.

thread.name: Phone connection to face to face meeting.

sent.#text: Charles asks whether there are people who would like to attend a meeting by phone.
He requests that those who will participate by phone let him know as soon as possible before early next week.
Phill and William say that they would.
Charles mentions that time-zone differences should be considered.
He and Phill resolve to work out the time differences.
Charles was arranging a telephone connection and was wondering if anyone would need this facility if they're unable to attend the meeting.
He was asking to respond asap since the decision would be made early the following week.
William said he would need this facility.
Marjolein said she'd like William to be present at the meeting.
Phil requested to be added to the list of "on the phone" preferably with an 800 number.
Charles commented about the time zone difference, and asked that those who intend to participate in a part of the meeting to indicate which part it would be.
Phil said he'll participate in the second half of the day and asked what would be a good time to call after Amsterdam's lunch time.
Charles said he'll let him know.
The topic is a proposal to arrange a telephone connection meeting in lieu of a face to face meeting.
A request is made for participants who would like to be a part of the telephone meeting.
The decision about the meeting will be made next week.

thread.name: html to word to html question?

sent.#text: The e-mails contain discussions regarding a programming language, and specifically regarding a question that David initiated on whether or not if you create a page with alt tags and bring it into word to edit it and then export it back to html that the alts are stripped.

Chris guessed that he would expect that to happen if David can confirm the scenario that it starts with an HTML document, and contains an with the ALT= attribute, the HTML doc is opened in Word and some text on the page is changed or added, and the page is "saved as HTML" from word, without first saving it in Word format.
Jamie also gave other explanations to David's questions as many people who are not web professionals required to edit and create web, and it is the only "WYSIWYG" tool available to them is Word.
In addressing the question as to why would people use Word to edit an HTML document, Alan replied that word is a good tool to do the job

However, Kynn suggested that Hot Metal Pro which is a web editor tool that does accessibility and valid HTML, also has the ability to import Word files which would save more time, rather than cutting and pasting and saving is as an HTML document.
Daniel also suggested to Chris that if he is interested in the kind of issue regarding html to word to html, then he should join the WAI Authoring Tools.
A person is asking whether it is true or not that exporting pages from Word to HTML means that the alts disappear
Another person offers to test this to see if it is true and asks for some clarification regarding the various commands and steps used to do this.
This person also asks why one would use Word to edit an HTML document
Several members respond to this question [3.1-3.4, 4.2-4.11,6.1-6.4,8.13]Two other members repeat the scenario and doe not have the same problem and try to explain why this may be the case

Other problems with trying to perform this are also discussed [8.7-8.10]. It is suggested that the original member asking the question join a working group that may be of interest relating to this issue
They discuss accessibility problems with editing HTML in Word, specifically if Word removes alt tags
They would like to test whether this happens.
Some do test it, and it seems that Word does not remove alt tags.
Word does appear to remove other tags.

Charles was wondering if there was anyone from the OpenOffice or StarOffice who had time to represent the group on the W3C Authoring Tool Accessibility Guidelines working group, or give feedback on how much those guidelines were implemented.
Liddy, Charles and Jan missed the call and Liddy wanted to discuss the possibility of a 'summit' at www11.
Jutta replied that they had a short meeting in which the summit was discussed, Heather wouldn't be able to come , IBM will be there.
Liddy submitted a request to hold it so that they don't need to go through paperwork.
Charles asks whether a representative of the StarOffice or OpenOffice projects could meet to discuss web accessibility guidelines.
A few people missed the call.
Jutta did not miss the call, and met with Phil and Heather.
They discussed a meeting and thought it was a good idea.
Heather will not be able to make it, but representatives of IBM will.
Liddy intends to follow up on this.
Someone is being asked to be a spokesperson in a Guidelines working group or to provide updates and feedback on the implementation of those guidelines
The information needed to do this is discussed
Three people missed the call due to sleeping in
A short meeting was held, where they discussed the Summit. One person won't be able to attend, but it is considered a worthwhile way to pull everything together
one person has put in a request to put a hold on the Summit.

thread.name: Extending IETF meetings to two weeks?

sent.#text: Jacob suggested to hold two week meetings, the first will discuss user service issues and all other issues the following week, he said people can attend one week or both.
Terry supported Jacob's idea and suggested a firmer scheduling.
Brian was against spreading the meetings thinner.
Larry commented that they could create the IETF schedule earlier without causing trouble.
Richard supported Larry and said it will help reduce travel costs which will help more people to attend.
Jacob suggests that future IETF meetings be spread over two weeks.
There are complaints that two-week meetings are not a good idea.
Some argue that it'd be more useful to prepare the meeting schedule earlier.
The topic is the logistics of scheduling IETF meetings
A suggestion is made to hold future meetings for two weeks to spread out the volume of participants
Also the suggestion that the meeting schedule be issued in advance by 21 days is made in order to allow participants better planning options.
Charles sends an email letting the group know that a face-to-face meeting is necessary and provides a time in October in Boston as a possibility.
Ian indicates that he can likely attend.
Kynn replies and states that he will likely be out of the country at the proposed time.
Charles then sends some administrative information, including the registration site and tips on booking accommodation in Boston.
Charles also asks the participants for their lunch request.
Charles informs the WAI Guidelines committee that there is a meeting planned to resolve issues and revamp the document.
He mentions a possible meeting in Boston during Oct 7 and 8.
Charles then adds that the meeting is planned for the same time as the ATIA meeting in Orlando.
He asks people to let him know if they cannot make the Boston meeting so it can be rescheduled.
Ian replies that he has other meetings scheduled in Boston at that time.
He can however probably start attending on Oct 7.
Kynn says he will be in Rome during that time and thus cannot attend.
Charles says that the meeting is confirmed for Boston Oct 7 and 8.
Registration is now open at the provided link.
Hotel rooms are available to be booked.
He asks people to contact him if they have questions.
Charles mentions a list of possible food choices.
He asks people to email him with their choices and if they wish to have certain foods avoided.
This thread is compiled from a list of communications from people who would like to have meeting to tidy up their issues.
The proposal is for the meeting to be in the Boston area on Thursday and Friday of October 7 and 8.
The meeting is at the same time as the ATIA meeting in Orlando, Florida.
The schedule may be changed to fit other people's schedules.
Ian replies saying that he may be able to attend
Allaire Corp will be the hosts for the meeting.
and meeting registration is open until the first of October through the website,  http://www.w3.org/WAI/AU/f2f-oct99
Charles is trying to organize the menu for the meeting.
Lovey said they had to define disability before defining accessibility since there are so many types of disabilities.
Kynn said that anyone should be able to access information, regardless of whether or not they have a "disability."
Alan commented that people aren't disabled and disability is really "a design flaw in the environment."
Kynn agreed with Alan and provided examples.

Lovely asks the thread participants to define disability and cites examples of causes of disability and cits some technologies that aid in accessibility of digital material. Lovely believes that accessibility can't be defined until disability is.

Kynn wonders why define the term, as in his view anyone should have the right to access information regardless of any quality one might have. He thinks it is fine to define accessibility without defining disability as long as we are not speaking only about access for people with the disability definition.
Alan provides a definition of disability as a define flaw in the environment.

Kynn agrees with Alan's definition and recounts that she tells people that the reason they can't access a web page is no fault of themselves but rather a problem with page itself, in it is inherently unaccessible. The web author was "disabled" in Kynn opinion for not making the page accessible.
Jonathan comments that Victorians probably had a hard time designing a wheelchair for quadriplegics.
Lovey proposes to define disability before defining accessibility.

However, Kynn thinks that anyone should be able to access information, regardless of whether or not they have "disabilities" (having certain qualities that other people do not have) and it's perfectly reasonable to define "accessibility" with having a strict definition of "disability" as long as your accessibility definition doesn't speak _only_ about access for people who fit that disability definition.
Kynn says that the problem is not that there's anything "wrong with" the user, but it is a problem with the page author and his output.
Alan also believe that disability is a design flaw in the environment.
Peter announces that he has made available an updated version of his paper on dyslexia and e-content accessibility.
He initially forgets to attach the paper or send a URL, which he does in a latter mail.
He also does not clarify, in the paper, what "SLD" stands for.
Again, he addresses his oversight in a later email, stating the "SLD" really only covers those with language disabilities.
He hopes to write a similar paper of wider scope sometime in the future.
Peter says he has completed an update for a paper about dyslexia and online accessibility.
It is available in HTML, MS Word, RTF, and PDF.
Bob asks for the URL to the paper.
Peter replies with the URL.
Jonathan asks whether SLD refers to dyslexia, or cognitive disability.
He adds that it is a good resource and he now links to it.
Peter says that the paper covers dyslexia, not cognitive disabilities.
He hopes in the future to write a similar paper about web accessibility for the hearing impaired.
Peter alerts everyone that he has finished a an update to a paper on Dyslexia and is made available in a variety of formats.
Bob asks for a URL and Peter provides one.

Jonathan comments that the paper is a good resource and recommends that to avoid confusion that Peter confirms that his use of the term SLD refers to 'specific learning difficulty or dyslexia' and not 'severe learning disability'.

Peter clarifies that the paper covers 'specific learning difficulty or dyslexia' and says that he has avoided discussion on severe disability and cognition as for that he would need to go into more detail.
He hopes to make a new paper in the future about web accessibility and deafness.
John sends an email to his list asking if Amaya allows the viewer of the site to modify the colours of the page so that vision impaired people can read the pages.
Irene replies by saying that Amaya is an editor and that the background and foreground colours can be altered by the viewer to promote enhanced viewing.
Charles then provides a short tutorial on how to change colours in pages such as the ones John refers to.
John asks whether Amaya allows the user to override a site's colour settings.
Irene says that Amaya doesn't allow this explicitly, but mentions that it's possible to edit a site so that the colours look different.
Charles suggests making a local stylesheet using !important declarations.
He explains how to code such a stylesheet.
Charles isn't certain whether such a stylesheet will work in Amaya.
Irene notes that Amaya does not yet take !important declarations into account.
The topic is the possibility of browsers (specifically AMAYA) allowing an override setting to change the colour on HTML Documents.
It is suggested that this feature is not available but that Amaya could lead the way in this direction

thread.name: Appropriate Use of Graphics, and Web Design by Blind People

sent.#text: Kynn starts the thread by wondering about the use of graphics in web pages and whether blind designers have a fair vantage point on this topic.
Charles indicates that some blind designers could work well with graphics, some couldn't just like anyone else.
Kynn disagrees because blind people may not be able to describe an image as accurately as a sighted person.
Leonard also agrees that it depends on the individual, not the level of ability that determines how well one will do with graphics.
There are web standards that be used to enhance the quality of pages produced.
Kynn asks if blind people will be good web designers assuming there is a requirement to use graphics "when appropriate".
Charles says that some would and some wouldn't.
Some blind people are visually capable, and some aren't.
He then asks whether blind people can accurately describe images.
Kynn replies that blind people can choose not to use images they cannot describe.
If images become a requirement, this is no longer an option.
He says he himself is unsure if he can provide good graphics.
However, he refuses to give up web design because people with disabilities need graphics.
Jonathan says that if all web authors feel that way, no wonder WAI is needed.
Leonard remarks on if graphics became required, there are ways for blind designers to use graphics just as effectively as sighted people, by using rules and charts.
As for creative art, he says there are some blind people who can produce very effective artwork.
Kynn asks Jonathan if Jonathan meant to be insulting.
Kynn says that if Jonathan questions his  "loyalty to cause", despite Kynn's proving  his loyalty, Jonathan is likely to turn away potential allies.
But, Kynn says, it may just be a communication error.
The topic is the question of whether or not a requirement to use graphics for web design would mean that blind people would not be good web designers.
The discussion explores the idea that sighted people can be just as handicapped when it comes to visual capability
Some suggestions are raised as to how the blind might overcome their perceived handicap when it comes to graphic selection in web design.

thread.name: RE: Meeting today - possible partial regrets

sent.#text: Marjolein says that it is likely that this meeting is long since it is a joint meeting and in case the meeting does not finish in one hour she has to leave early because she has to attend a phone meeting.
Jan sends the unfinished Techniques draft that he had promised at the face-to-face.
Language specific things have generally been removed from the draft (to be put in the separate docs).

Charles thinks that Jan has done a good job but he propose to have the following categories: +Things you need to do to meet the checkpoint (these can be fairly general) + Techniques to do this (which should say how much of it they do) + Things which are good to do although they go beyond the requirements of the checkpoint. + References and they probably need to be sorted (where applicable) by tool type and priority.
Jan agrees with Charles and says that he would like to work on emphasizing cross-over situations.
A member of a listserv is sending his potential regrets that he may have to leave a meeting early, as requested by an earlier email instructing members to send regrets via the listserv.
Another member attaches a promised document draft for everyone to look over prior to the meeting.
Another member comments that it's good and suggests several categories for sorting the information into.
The member who created the draft agrees with this and mentions the items she would like to emphasize.
Marjolein did not know how long the meeting was going to take but it would possibly be a long meeting than a short one.
Jan just sent the Techniques draft after a long delay, although, it was not entirely finished yet.

In reply to Jan's e-mail, Charles suggested that the draft should have the following categories of: Things Jan needs to do to meet the checkpoint (these can be fairly general), Techniques to do this (which should say how much of it they do), Things which are good to do although they go beyond the requirements of the checkpoint, References
these would all need to be sorted by tool type and priority.
Libby wrote to the list asking for data: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-rdf-interest/2003Apr/0252.html.
She asked people to add themselves to the group and constructed demos displaying the existing information: http://www.w3.org/2001/sw/Europe/200303/geo/intro.html#demos.

She noted that a map that highlighted Europe was required and posted two designs: http://www.cadmium.co.uk/thumbs/brand%20x/maps%20and%20globes/t_bxp_c31027.jpg.jpg had the advantage of showing Europe as a part of the world and http://www.cadmium.co.uk/thumbs/ds/maps%20and%20globes/t_11407324.jpg.jpg was simpler to do but showed Europe solely.
She asked people to let her know asap about their preference since she wanted to get postcards for www2003.
Ian preferred the map and wondered why it had to be geographically accurate, he suggested using a schematic.
Dan replied that by being geographically accurate it's simpler to plot SW researchers, events etc on the map and he also preferred the map.
Libby said they needed examples to shows the designer and promised to pass Ian's comments to him, she also wondered what he didn't like about the examples.
Ian said the globe was too visually busy for a background and the map missed the rest of the world and the ocean's took too much place.
Libby agreed with Ian but said they could put a logo on the ocean.
A member of a listserv is asking for feedback in terms of what map will be used as a background for a postcard outlining the location of Semantic web researchers and groups.

Two are suggested, with possible advantages and disadvantages of each presented.[1.11-1.15] Members are asked if they prefer one over the other and to let her know today, as the printing needs to get done very soon.
One member replies and states that he doesn't really like either, but has a vague preference for the map over the globe.
he also asks why the background has be geographically accurate and suggests another approach.
Another member gives a possible answer to this question, saying it will be easier in the long run.
He closes by saying he too likes the map best.
The original poster apologizes for and explains the reason for the time crunch and says she will pass along comments to the designer and wants particular feedback re: why people don't like them.
A member responds and tells her exactly why he doesn't like either choice.
She responds with agreement but offers a reason for part of the design.
Libby is trying to make a map of where semantic web researchers are located.
She sent out some examples and asked for others' opinions.
The others don't like the globe.
They provide some suggestions, including a more abstract representation.

thread.name: Federal Credit Union Question ADA related

sent.#text: Suzanne asks whether 508 applies to federal credit unions.
There is some debate whether or not they do: many say they do not.
Bob mentions that they are, not because they are federal agencies, but because they are under the ADA.
Suzanne asks someone to give her a lead on who she can talk to about accessibility of Federal Credit Union websites.
She also asks if 508 applies to said unions.
Dan gives a link to describe what the Credit Unions are.
He doubts that they are covered by 508.
John says that is no reason to not make the sites accessible.
Demonpenta makes a joke sarcastically in their defense.
He imagines they are poor in day to day cash.
Rex says that these unions are not federal agencies, but owned by their members.
They are regulated.
However, they do not fall under 508.
Bob says that they DO fall under ADA, and that requires "equivalent facilitation" which could require a usable website.
Suzanne requests for a website or a federal department representative to contact regarding the accessibility of Federal Credit union websites.
Suzanne also wonders if the 508 applies to the Federal Credit Unions.
Dan responds to Suzanne given her a link to webpage and comments that the doubts credit unions follow the 508 as they are owned by the members that founded them.
John comments that such ownership is not a reason to make a site not accessible.
A user Demonpenta2 comments that credit unions have a small defense in not making sites accessible, as they are low in day to day cash.
David responds to Suzanne's initial question and comments that credit unions are not federally owned but are regulated and provides a web link.
He also comments that credit unions are not covered under the 508.
User Access Systems comments that credit unions do, however, follow under the ADA which requires "equivalent facilitation" that could allow allow for the 508 to be used as a guideline.

thread.name: U.S. won't release new Web site regs for review

sent.#text: Kathleen passes a website link to everyone. The website is a forum based on a nonpartis, international foundation dedicated to free press, free speech, and free spirit for all people.
Kynn believes that not one belongs to the WAI or the HTML Writers Guild.
She does not think too highly about a journalist named Adam Clayton Powell III, whom she believes to be a fearmonger and irresponsible journalist.
Kelly asks about the release of all the 508 accessibility regulations and asks a question about he approach of the federal government.
Kynn does not know the question to Kelly's question but tries to offer some insights and leads.
Medlina agrees with Kynn, and offers more opinions on the matter.
Al pretty much agrees with everything.
Christopher makes fun about Adam Clayton Powell III by comparing him to Thurston Powell III on a popular retro show.
Jeffrey offers some suggests and makes some requests
He also defends the government.
A member of the listserv posts a link to the Freedom Forum which contains a document that states that the U.S. won't release new website regulations to be reviewed.
A member comments on this posting, giving her personal opinion that the journalist who wrote this article is crazy and a fearmonger.
Another member wants to know why the government is stalling the release of the accessibility regulations, which did not go through as expected.
A member responds and gives the possible explanation that beauracracy is to blame rather than government policy and  provides a contact name to ask.
Another member agrees with this last comment and thinks it will be released eventually.
Another member provides an explanation of the Federal Register and government policy and a link to find out more information.

Another member states that this is a good question and should be brought up at the next meeting and for all other questions of this nature to also be brought up then. The members are asked to find out when the webcast is happening.

This same member posts again and expresses the opinion that the government is doing the opposite of what it appears and is protecting us, which takes time due to lack of staff to sift through the information.

According to an online article on the internet, the Freedom Forum is a nonpartisan, international foundation dedicated to free press, free speech and free spirit for all people and that it pursues its priorities through various programs such as conferences, educational activities, publishing, etc.
Kynn had a personal opinion about Adam Clayton Powell III, Kynn thought that Adam was a fearmonger and irresponsible journalist and that he was just a kook
Kynn did not see the feds took a closed-door approach from the way they read their announcement

However, Kynn also suggested that to clarify the issue regarding whether or not it was a typical bureaucracy slowness or concerted conspiracy, Mr. Yanchulis is the guy to ask for clarification in the matter.
To get further information, Al also suggested that they could consult the Federal Register from their website.
Jeffrey solidified the argument that the government was protecting them instead of robbing them from their rights.
Jason mentions that he has found textual transcripts of radio broadcasts by Australia's ABC on the web.
He wonders if there are other radio stations that provide these on the web.
Others respond that CNN and Public Radio International also provide transcripts.
Jason mentions that transcripts of audio content are part of the accessibility guidelines.
Somewhat off topic, Michael asks for a place to read about guidelines relating to colour blindness.
Jason says that he has found that ABC Radio in Australia now offers online transcripts of its programmes.
The transcripts appear some days after the original broadcast.
He asks whether other radio stations are adopting similar policies.
Mr. Raman says CNN is doing the same and gives a link.
The page has lots of tables however.
Pfhyper says Public Radio International offers audio transcripts of some of their shows.
Jason says that providing transcripts of audio is a requirement, so if there is an audio stream provided, there must be transcripts.
Michael introduces a new topic and asks where he can find the specifics about issues of web pages and color blindness.
Kynn replies with a few links for Michael.
Michael thanks everyone for the quick response to his question.
Jason comments that he found out recently that a radio station in Australia offers transcripts for some programs a few days after the broadcast of a program.
Jason asks if similar policies are adopted by other radio stations with web presence.
Raman suggests a URL for Jason regarding CNN and its transcripts.
Fleck responds with a URL to Jason that shows that Public Radio International also provides transcripts for their shows.
Jason comments that providing transcripts is required under the guidelines, when an audio stream is provided.

Michael asks where is a good resource for the issue of color blindness and the web.[] Kynn provides Michael several links to resources (AWARE Centre and Diane Wilson's site) and Michael thanks her and everyone.
Keith is wondering if there will be anything happening at CHI 2003 related to W3C user interest group and he proposes to have an informal SIG meeting during the conference.
Sharon says that she will be attending CHI and before planning an informal SIG she would like to get some updated info on Steven Pemberton's charter draft.
However, she is willing to meet if there is an interest in meeting at CHI.
Chip thinks that they decided at the NIST meetings to have the next meeting at CHI, and he is wondering if the plan has changed because has been planning on such a meeting there.
Sharon confirms that there will be a meeting at CHI on Tuesday 4/8 1-2:30pm. She thinks that the meeting will take less than 90 minutes so it will be still time for lunch.
A member of a listserv is asking other members if there will be an informal meeting relating to the W3C interest group at CHI 2003.
This will be beneficial for those that did not attend the workshop and wish to find out what is happening.
There is time urgency involved, as there will most likely be many activities which also would take place at the same time.
Another member has asked for an update of the W3C charter so as to be better informed when planning an informal meeting.
She states that she will try to arrange an informal meeting if people are interested and asks that people email her to express their interest.
Another member comments that the listserv has been quiet for awhile and wants everyone to keep their enthusiasm up.
Another member is confused, as he assumed there would be a meeting, as discussed at a previous meeting, and asks for clarification.
A plan has been put in place and there will be an informal meeting. People are asked to email the most convenient meeting times and these will try to be accommodated.
A first choice of meeting times is presented, as well as a back up time, which will be confirmed later via the listserv.
An email is sent later confirming the date and time of the informal meeting.
Keith was wondering if there was anything at the CHI 2003 conference related to W3C User interest group and since he hasn't seen anything on the program he suggested to plan an informal SIG ASAP.
Sharon said she'd be at CHI but wanted to get an update on a Steven Pemberton's draft of the charter and its status at W3C before committing to the SIG.
She also said that she'd arrange a meeting if Keith will e-mail her that he's interested.
Chip has been planning for such a meeting in CHI and wanted to check if it was still happening.
Sharon signed up for an informal SIG at CHI and asked people who were interested to attend for time constraints so she would be able to schedule the meeting.
Sharon announced that the most convenient time for the SIG would be Tuesday 4/8 1-2:30pm and Wednesday 4/9 1-2:30 will be the backup.
She said she'll email the informal SIG people and confirm via the contact list and after confirmed the Informal SIG time slot at CHI for Tuesday 4/8 1-2:30.

thread.name: better Australian time for regular teleconferences

sent.#text: Jutta is concerned that Liddy has to get up at 2am to receive calls from the team and recommends a time that is convenient for everyone across time zones. He recommends 4 pm EDT on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.
Jan agrees that that is a good time and cites some examples of times of day in some countries.
Liddy thanks Jutta and brings up that the Tuesday might conflict with IMS meetings.
Carlos responds that he can make some calls at the proposed time but not at other times, but understands the need for change.

Lou writes in behalf of a Heather and says that she may have conflicts and she may or may not be able to resolve those conflicts, but she will be back next week to make her own decision and Lou asks when a firm response is needed by.
liddy wonders if it is better to switch times and notifies everyone she will be Europe for a little while.
Doug responds and says anytime is ok with him.

Heather responds and says that Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday at 4:00 pm EST would work but Tuesday or Wednesday would be better for her and notifies that Lou will sit in for her for the next call. She asks if the next call is scheduled for the Monday at 12 EST.

The discussions in the e-mails are about deciding the teleconference time that is best for everyone since they are all in different parts of the world with significant time differences between the countries.  The concern was first due to one of the meeting attendee, Liddy, who had to wake up at 2am on a regular basis for the teleconference.
And thus, Jutta had suggested that they find an alternative time that works for everyone who are involved in the teleconference.
Jutta suggested a teleconference time at 4:00pm EDT on Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday.

However, due to the different schedule that everyone has, other meeting times would have been difficult to agree upon since it would conflict with other meeting schedule and thus it would be difficult to find a common time that works for every time zone in different countries.
Jutta proposes to find a more convenient meeting time for everyone which takes into account European time, Australian time and both east and west coast North American time.
Jutta suggests 4:00pm EDT on Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday and asks if anyone has an alternative suggestion.
Jan thinks that this is a good time but Liddy says that Tuesday 4 pm EDT would clash with IMS meetings.
Carlos says that it is very hard to find a time that works for everyone and having the meeting at 10 pm East European time means that he cannot make all of the calls.
Liddy says that she will be soon in Europe for few weeks and asks if it heps to have different times.
Doug says that he is comfortable with whatever time is set.
Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday at 4:00 pm EST is good for Heather but Tuesday or Wednesday would be better.
She informs that she is back but Lou Nell is going to sit in on the next call for her.
She also asks if the meeting time is still Monday at 12:00 EST.

thread.name: Mozilla 1.2 and keyboard to activate links?

sent.#text: Jonathan mentions a new feature of Mozilla that allows users to search for links by typing.
He asks the others what they think of it.
Some users like it and use it a lot.
Jonathan mentions that the feature screws his coding somehow.
Iris asks how, but is not answered.
Jonathan also believes that the feature may be bad for some users.
Jonathan says that Peepo has advocated using a keyboard to select links.
However, in the latest Mozilla browser, he says doing this is slightly buggy.
It also affects his coding.
Iris responds that she has been using the typeaheadfind function for a few days.
She has no problems with it.
It's more of a find function rather than cycling through links.
The tab key should be used for cycling through links.
Iris asks how Jonathan's coding is affected.
Timoty agrees that the typeaheadfind function is good.
He likes Opera's similar inline find function.
Jonathan says it is buggy in the sense that k words are not just those that start with k, but those that include the letter k.
He expects other bugs as well.
Jonathan comments that Peepo has suggested the using the keyboard as a way to select links for years.

Jonathan states that the latest Mozilla browser will cycle through links if one types a letter anywhere other than an empty text box and comments the feature is somewhat buggy and interferes with his coding.
Jonathan asks the opinion of others in the thread on this topic.
Iris responds that she stumbled upon the same feature a few days ago and does not find it buggy.
She continues to comment that the feature is simply a more elegant "find" feature and is not that suitable for cycling through links.
Iris comments that the tab key works better for cycling through links.
Iris asks Jonathan how does the Mozilla feature interfere with his coding.

Timothy comments that he like Opera's (another web browser) 'inline find' (and provides a web link to that feature) and 'ctrl-j' feature which Timothy describes as a feature that lists all links on a page and provides an opportunity to see if the links make sense when read out of context.
Jonathan responds with a suggestion of disabling keyboard features for those who are prone to fiddle with the keyboard.
He also explains why he thinks the Mozilla feature is buggy.
Charles suggested Ottawa, 5 or 6 October or Nashville, mid October to hold a meeting and asked for people's opinions.
William suggested to have a meeting about something concrete and commented that it would be helpful for more than one WG to meet around the same time.
Heather was in for a face-to-face meeting and had no preference for the dates.

Jutta said she and Norman Coombs will be on accessible courseware authoring in the Nashville conference and provided info on the event http://www.educause.edu/conference/e2000, she suggested to have small working meetings with a set of tasks to create drafts and then gather as a whole to review.
An idea is raised to have a face-to-face meeting and two possible locations and dates are given.
People are asked how they feel about them, if there should even be such an in person meeting at all and also to recommend other viable alternatives if the present ones are not acceptable.
One ember responds saying he thinks that such a meeting is not necessary due to lack of agenda items that lend themselves to an in person meeting.
Another member thinks it is a good idea and likes both suggested dates.
Another member provides information about the Nashville conference (one of the alternatives).
This member also explains what is envisioned for the in person meeting, saying it will be a working meeting with set tasks to accomplish.
They are wondering if they should schedule a face-to-face meeting and in that case what the good time and location would be.
Charles is prosing to hold the meeting wither in Ottawa from October 5-6 or Nashville in mid October.
William thinks that they are not ready for a face-to-face meeting and he thinks it would be good if the meeting happens in conjunction with some other meeting.
Heather is in favour of such a meeting and both location and time would work for her.
Jutta prefers Nashville and she informs people that the Education conference is happening there from October 10-13.

thread.name: Re: A poll for screen reader users

sent.#text: Scott talks about a poll of screen reader users in which most users preferred a version of a webpage formatted specifically for screen readers over one that wasn't.
Scott mentions a few minor problems with the poll.
He also mentions that users wanted more text in the version for screen readers.
The remainder of the thread is a discussion of the accessibility of esight.org.
Michael is uncertain whether screen readers would be able to work with the site's code.
Patrick seems to think that screen readers will deal fine with it.
Scott says 24 screen reader users have voted in a poll between the screen reader version and the standard version.
One person disliked the screen reader version.
The reason was due to a misunderstanding on the user's part.
Two users forgot to choose.
21 users preferred the screen reader version.
Some users wanted more text on the screen reader version.
Michael introduces a different topic and asks whether anyone has heard of www.esight.org.
He asks whether that site is accessible.
Scott says 24 screen reader users have voted in a poll between the screen reader version and the standard version.
One person disliked the screen reader version.
The reason was due to a misunderstanding on the user's part.
Two users forgot to choose.
21 users preferred the screen reader version.
Some users wanted more text on the screen reader version.
Michael introduces a different topic and asks whether anyone has heard of www.esight.org.
He asks whether that site is accessible.
Patrick says that all he can see are the "notify" and "beta tester" links.
There is nothing about what the site does.
It is nothing but hype.
Michael asks how a screen reader would handle that code.
He asks Patrick to look at the source.
Patrick says the code is not unusual.
Unless he is missing a CFM-generated applet, the code seems normal.
Scott reports that 24 users of screen readers have sent in their votes and summarizes some of the results he received.
Michael asks if anyone had heard of a URL and asks if the site is accessible because he knows little about cold fusion sites.
Patrick responds to Michael and says he only receives "notify" and "beta user" links and is unclear on what the site does.
Michael wonders how a screen reader could interpret the code on the site and recommends looking at the source code.
Patrick comments that he does not get any unusual code with a few minor exceptions.
The thread begins with Rob emailing a list indicating that he has been unsuccessful from getting off the list and is resorting to posting a message to the group requesting that he be removed.
Kimberly also wants to be off the mailing list and requests that the administrator fix the unsubscribe feature on the automated list.

Hakon, with the emailing list group, offers reasons why the first two posters have been unsuccessful in removing themselves from the list and asks that they speak to their system administrator about the issue.
Rob then shares with everyone that he has been removed from the list.
Sam also requests to be taken off the list.
Rob says that one cannot unsubscribe from the list.
He has tried for months to get off, unsuccessfully.
So he has decided to post to the list that he wants off of.
Kim says that she is in the same situation.
She asks to be taken off the list.
She also asks for the automated subscribe/unsubscribe function to be fixed.
Hakon says the automated manager works fine.
He says problems may occur for various reasons.
He asks people to talk to their sysadmn about problems.
He says there is nothing they can do.
Rob says that he responded with an unsubscribe email and received the response that his name was not on the list.
He says he is calm.
However, he wants off the list.
Rob then says that he is now off the list.
This is because he posted his problems to the list.
That shows it works, he says.
Sam quotes Kim's plea to be taken off the list.
Sigrolly sends an unsubscribe email.
Rob complains that there is no way to unsubscribe to the mailing list.
Despite his best efforts, all he can do is write to the list.
Other subscribers mention that they also would like off the list.
Hakon claims that the trouble is not with the mailing list software, but with email aliases or group subscriptions
Eventually, Rob is removed from the mailing list.

The e-mails contain discussions regarding an advanced planning for a Face to Face meeting in September  and due to the membership overlap with the OASIS BPEL TC, they would like to try and co-locate with their meetings.
although it will not be a joint meeting with the OASIS and is being proposed purely due to ease travel logistics and members' costs
The proposed meeting time from the OASIS TC are the 17th, 18th, 19th of September, either in Seattle or in Germany.
therefore they would then try to meet on the 15th, 16th, and the 17th of September.
The meeting in Germany, will be in Waldorf, not far from Heidelberg.

The e-mail also indicated that if Germany is the chosen place for the meeting, then those who want to attend both meetings will get a weekend in Heidelburg, however, if the BPEI decides to meet in Seattle, the possibility to have a weekend stayover is low.
Martin says that they are planning for a F2F in September and because of the membership overlap between F2F and OASIS BPEL TC they would like to co-locate with their meetings.
This co-location is proposed to make travel logistics easier and lower the costs.

Since OASIS TC is meeting on 17 (afternoon), 18, and 19 September, either in Seattle or Germany, it makes sense to try and meet on 15, 16, and 17 (Morning) September. Martin asks everyone to check if they are available for the proposed dates and inform the chairs.
SAP has already offered to host the meeting in Waldorf (not far from Heidelberg) in Germany, but if BPEL TC decide to meet in Seattle, a host is needed.
Monica says that the proposed meeting dates overlap with SunNetworks and asks if they could schedule the meetings for the week after OASIS TC.
Although Martin says that it is possible to schedule the meetings for the week after, they should not get into an n-phase transaction.
Advanced planning to organize a face-to-face meeting for September is being discussed.
There is another meeting planned around the same time so there is a desire to have both meetings in the same place for the sake of convenience, even though both are separate meeting
Meeting dates of September 15, 16 and 17 are mentioned in either Seattle or Germany.
People are asked to check their diaries to see if they can attend and let the chairs know as soon as possible.
If it is held in Germany there is already a host that has come forward, but if it is held in Seattle a host would need to be found
A request for hosts is extended.
A person asked where in germany the meeting would be held and was told it would be in Waldorf
A member states that the meeting dates conflict with another meeting and wants to see if the following week is possible instead
The logistics of this proposal are discussed
Jonathan has cross-posted a discussion about the use of animation in web design.
William brings up some point of the post that he does not fully grasp yet. He understands the concept of making pages less text-heavy for ease of  but not ease of reading.
Kynn respond to William and suggests that is not necessarily that reading requires text.
Kynn suggests a book he uses himself about the blend between graphic media and text media to everyone titled "Understanding Comics".
David asks if anyone has a dictionary handy.
Theo request more information from Jonathan about the topic because he is doing an Msc in a related topic.
Al asks Kynn if the book is shared on Kynn.com and asks if Kynn is willing to share useful references.
Kynn thinks that Al has a good idea and encourages everyone to share their bookshelf collections if relevant to WAI activities.
Jonathan says he has copied a post from Cynthia.
The post talks about a set of animated gifts and their effect on people with epilepsy.
She says these gifs are no problem.
She had been in the field of online design and cognition.
After her accident, she had to change that.
She says she is pleased someone is helping to make reading and communication better in a text-heavy environment.
William asks how reading can be possible in an environment that is not text-heavy.
After all, what one reads is text.
Kynn remarks that a lot of reading is non-textual.
Scott McCloud's "Understanding Comics" is a good example of this.
Kynn remarks that he owns the book.
David asks if anyone has a dictionary.
Ali says she is doing a degree in Computer Studies and her project is about web accessibility for people with learning disabilities.
She asks if Jonathan could explain his work in that area.
Al asks if Kynn's book collection is documented on Kynn's site.
Kynn says he will post his collection tomorrow.
He also encourages others to do the same, if it is relevant to WAI.
The initial topic is a forwarded thank you email.
The emailer is also grateful for being consulted about the effect of animated gifs on his epilepsy.
The subsequent email exchange is on the topic of reading and communication in this text-heavy environment.
It is suggested that reading does not always imply text and resource material is noted

Alan brings up that an amateur web developer and professional disability rights advocate has complained about the W3C guidelines being overly technical and proposes to create a "user-friendly" version of the Web content guidelines.
Robert appears to want to remind people that he was the first to come up with this proposal and then asks about a potential meeting.
William agrees with the proposal
Chuck suggests the WCAG curriculum
Jonathan suggests that ideas.
Judy tried the link and found that it did not work.
Alan spoke with a friend who is a web designer that is frustrated with the technical guidelines if the W3C.
For her needs, a simple plain language guideline would be better and Alan wonders if it would be best they made a user-friendly version of the guidelines, perhaps a primer.
Robert says that Alan is not the first to ask about this topic and he agrees, as he made comments about a "create a wcag for dummies" in Toronto lat year.
He also asks of there will be EO, WAI, and WCAG meetings at the www9.
William agrees that a primer is an excellent idea and asks if Alan would take it as an action item.

Chuck proposes simplifying the WCAG Curriculum, especially the example set section and provides links, but also warns that the curriculum will be moved to a different server so bookmarks to it will become invalid.
Jonathan links to website called www.peepo.com/access to illustrate how to approach simplifying the guidelines and asks that authors use good examples over text.
Judy writes backk to Jonathan that the link is invalid.
Alan says his friend commented that the W3C guidelines use arcane technical language
and that there should be a normal language version.
Alan agrees that a lot of web developers would not understand the technical language
and suggests they create a user-friendly version of the guidelines.
Robert says that he brought up this idea last year
and asks if there are going to be meetings of certain groups at the wwww9.
William says Alan's idea is good
and asks whether they are going to start work on it.
Chuck notes the WCAG Curriculum
and notes that it will be moving to W3C space soon.
Once that happens, WAI EO will likely start promoting it.
Jonathan says that the work of normal language guidelines has been started and gives a link.
He asks Alan to post his work if Alan is serious about doing it.
Judy remarks that Jonathan's link is broken.
Graham asks if anyone knows of websites that are highly accessible and well-liked by deaf users.
There are many, and several people send him relevant URLs.
Some of these, he is warned, are in languages other than English.
Graham asks if anyone knows of websites that are accessible to and well-liked by the deaf community.
Jonathan suggests the Federation of Deaf People's site, and gives a link.
Charles suggests Elokuvantaju.
It has sign-language available, but only finnish sign language.
Emmanuelle gives a website for Spanish people.
She also gives a site for the confederation.
Graciela gives a few other sites in Spanish.
Rachel recommends the Deaf World Web site.
Jonathan recommends about ten or so sites.
Graham asks if there are any well-liked, highly accessible websites as suggested by the deaf community.
Jonathan responds with a link suggested to him from 'The Federation of Deaf People'.
Charles responds to Graham and provides a link to Elokuvantaju - CinemaSense.
Charles comments that this site has sign language in Finnish only, for the moment.
Emmanuelle responds to Graham with two suggested links one for Spanish speakers and one from the Confederation.
Graciela provides Graham with links to two more Spanish sites

Rachel joins the thread and comments that during her experience as therapist for the deaf, she knew many people who liked 'Deaf World Web', but notes that the site is discontinued, but offers a link to another site.
Jonathan suggests yet another link for Graham.
Jonathan then suggests a long list of links at the end of the thread.
The email dialog started with Doyle asking if PDF files made on Mac computers were still not accessible when using Acrobat 6.0 for Macs.
Loretta from Adobe replied and said that the Make Accessible command was available for Acrobat 6.0 Professional and Acrobat 6.0 Standard for Mac computers.
Sailesh then enters the conversation and inquires about the function of the Make Accessible command.
Loretta replies by stating that Make Accessible works to analyze untagged PDF files so that the structure of the document can be viewed.
Doyle asks whether there is an accessibility option for authoring PDFs on a Macintosh in the latest version of Acrobat.
Loretta says that there is.
Sailesh asks what this feature actually does, since he does not notice any improvement after using it on PDFs.
Loretta answers Sailesh, explaining how the accessibility feature is like OCR on the structure of a PDF.
She notes that the feature is meant for PDF authors, not users.
The main topic is the question and answers as to whether or not Acrobat can make PDF files accessible if the files were actually developed on a Macintosh.
The discussion then turns to the "Make Accessible" feature of Acrobat
Jutta is trying to get some input on when and where to schedule a conference, list constraints and asks for suggestions.
Liddy suggests that a possible venue be Savannah and wants clarification on the date of the IMS meeting.
Tim responds that he is good for any date.
Roberto suggests that Venice be the locale of choice.
Charles agrees with the Venice suggestion.
Liddy is excited about the Venice suggestion and suggests that while they are at it they should plan a year ahead for other venues.
Jutta agrees with Liddy that planning forward is a good idea.
This email is a compilation of people discussing the possibility of a meeting together with the ATIA conference.
Jutta already has an IMS meeting on Saturday and Sunday afternoon on January 17 and 18.
Several other people are also unavailable prior to the ATIA meetings.
Liddy wishes for the meeting to be set at Orlando in Savannah.
Tim is fine with any time or venue.
Robert suggests that Venice is a possibility.
Charles likes Robert's suggestion as he has never been to Venice for a meeting.
Liddy wants to come to the meeting and is trying hard to make it so.
Juta thinks that planning early for at lest  is a good idea.

The e-mails discussed a face to face meeting possibility with the ATIA conference, and they have two options, which are to plan their meetings in Orlando, but not through ATIA since ATIA does not want any meetings to overlap with their events or to hold the meetings on Monday the 19th and Tuesday the 20th.

Other people to whom the e-mail was addressed to, started replying and identified their personal constraints regarding the meeting and whether they had any objections or they did not have any objection regarding the time and venue of the meeting.
In addition to discussing the face to face meeting, there was also a discussion regarding the meeting place for next year, Roberto suggested Venice for next year's conference.
In reply to the e-mail, Liddy suggested that for next year's planning that Australia can be included.
as well Jutta also thought that planning meetings a year in advance is a good idea to accommodate next year's meeting.
Brian is trying to cancel this week's telecon and reschedule it for another time. He wants to move up on the comments on the TAG architecture document.
Jeremy reveals more information about the likely decision to cancel this week's telecon and expressed his unhappiness that things are not being done.
Brian shares his opinion on what could be problems
and is prepared to decide by email so that they can formally respond by email.
Pat plans to write a rather long diatribe on the comments on the TAG architecture document.
Patrick doesn't care if anyone else in the WG not agreeing with him. Jeremy offers some more contents and says that he is happy to draft a formal response for e-mail voting.
Brian comments and mentions that he has been announcing elecon's in advance and canceling if not needed to keep within w3cprocess.
Mcbride proposes to cancel this week's teleconference and reschedule to another date (Mar 12, 2004). He wishes to get ahead on commenting the TAG architecture document.
Carroll asks  if he should tell governing body that informed a governing body that they will not respond to 18N. Mcbride's suggestion and has not met any unhappiness.
Mcbride asks if asking is a problem and asks when the deadline is and says he is ready to decide and respond by e-mail.
Hayes writes back in response to Mcbrides original question and assumes the telecon is canceled and assumes all are canceled unless she hears otherwise.
She also plans to write a response to the WG that she doubts the WG will endorse.
Patrick agress with Hayes.
Carroll writes that he too will make a draft and says the deadline is 2 weeks from when they write at an event called the Cannes.
Mcbride responds that the deadline date proposed by Carroll is a reasonable assumption.
Brian proposed to everyone in the e-mail list to cancel this week's telecon and schedule another one if needed, he would also like to get moving on comments on the TAG architecture document.
Jeremy replied to the e-mail by communicating his thought that the e-mail from Brian means that they would not formally respond to 18N on the charmod comments
in addition, Jeremy had also informaed the RDF Core WG of Brian's decisions and no one has indicated unhappiness in response to that decision
however, Jeremy also noted that they have not formally discussed those issues and Brian was prepared to respond by e-mail so that they can formally respond by e-mail to the RDF Core WG.
In response to Brian's first e-mail, Pat said that he still planned to write a rather long diatribe on the TAG Architecture document should he find the time to do it.
The deadline to formally respond by e-mail is 2 weeks after Patrick received the message which is during Cannes.
And Jeremy is going to draft a formal response for the e-mail vote.

thread.name: Text unavailable to sighted users but available to screen reader users

sent.#text: Graham asks if it is acceptable to hide text using colours to make it accessible only to users using screen readers.
David warns that the text would be accessible to other users.
It may also be misconstrued as an SEO technique and result in bad rankings on some search engines.
Charles mentions that the colour hiding technique may not work for all screen readers.
Anthony suggests putting the text in an image's ALT tag.
Jon says that this may not work, and may still cause problems with search engines.
Graham says he has made a form which includes a submit button.
If one presses submit but has not correctly completed the form, an alert will pop-up, giving more information.
But this is in breach of checkpoint 10.1.
He asks whether he could provide a warning message before the submit button that is the same color as the background.
This would make the text available to screen reader users but not sighted users.
David says that will not work on devices who display colours incorrectly.
Also, it is an old trick for stuffing keywords for search engines and may get the site blacklisted by major search engines.
Charles adds that some screen readers will realize the text is invisible and skip it.
Anthony says that Graham could try using a spacer image and putting the message in the alt text.
This could help bypass the search engine problem.
Jon says that might not work since that trick is also old and well-known.
This practice of spider-baiting is a problem for text users, whether sighted or not.
Graham comments that h e has built a form with submit button that if the form is not correctly filled out, a pop-up alert will appear.

He feels this may be breeching of a rule called checkpoint 10.1 and asks if it is acceptable to provide a warning message in the same color as the background making the text available to screen readers but not regular users.
David comments that the text would show up on devices that cannot handle color and comments that this was an old trick for putting key words into search engines.
Charles comments that screen readers 'smart' about color would skip the hidden message.
Anthony replies with a suggestion of using spacer images  and then put the message in the alternate text.
He doesn't know how this interacts with a screen reader but it will get around the search engine problem.
Jon comments on some information about web spiders and how they work.

thread.name: Location of August 30-31 1999 Face to Face

sent.#text: Donald is going with the University of California, Irvine location and will provide more info as it comes.
Bard apologizes for not responding earlier as he thought it was at the end of the week and offers to have the meeting in Seattle, but California is ok with him too.
Mark asks if the decision is made yet as he favors Seattle.
Peter jokes about going to a certain shop.
Bard jokingly says he'll check on that shop.
Donald says that the w3c rules requires a 6 week advance notice to change venues so unless they plan to skip this meeting they must go to California.
Todd throws in his preference for Washington because of convenience and personal experience, but is willing to entertain California.
Bard reminds everyone that Donald's post sealed the deal and the location is California, Irvine.

The e-mails contain discussions regarding the meeting place, whether it is going to be in Seattle or at the Univ. of Calif. at Irvine locations.  Although not everyone agreed to meet at the Univ. of Calif. at Irvine locations, however, the meeting place has been decided by Donald that it is going to be at the Univ. of Calif, since he hasn't heard from anyone else regarding their meeting location preferences ahead of time.
The meeting place in Irvine has been decided
eventhough Mark and Todd preferred to meet in Seattle because it is easier to get to anywhere else
and for Barb either location is fine
Since no one has suggested any place for the meeting, Don is suggesting University of California in Irvine.
Barb prefers Microsoft office in Seattle.
Mike, Peter and Todd are also willing to hold the meeting in Seattle under certain circumstances.
However, since they need to report the venue 6 week prior they decide to go with the UC Irvine location.
Further information about the meeting will be available soon.
Leonard welcomes the people and introduces the Web accessibility initiative evaluation and repairs. He asks each one to say a few words about themselves and their involvements in this area.
Daniel attaches his own description below. He is a overall WAI project manager and also chair of the evaluation & amp; repair working group.
Gilman introduces himself also and offers some opinions on the things they may do in the future.
Gregg then introduces himself  .
Phil also introduces himself and tells everyone about his credentials. Finally, Kitch introduces himself. He is a graduate student who is working on his doctoral dissertation.
Leonard welcomes everyone to the WAIERIG.
The group will be giving advice on tools for handling websites.
He asks people to give a brief description of themselves.
He then says he worked for AT&T Bell Labs, and is the chair of the group.
Daniel says he works for W3C.
He has been working for it since 1996.
He states that the work they are about to do is very important.
Al says he is the chair of a WAI group.
He also is on the Trace Center Team.
He has been in discussion with webmasters from the U.S. government.
Gregg says he is on a research group at the U of Wisconsin working on accessibility and information technologies.
He looks forward to the discussions here.
Phill says he works for IBM.
He is experienced in dealing with usability and disabilities.
He reaffirms his commitment to the group.
Kitch says he works for the American Foundation for the Blind.
He is also a grad student.
He is interested in usability testing techniques.

Len Kadsay, as the chair, opens the email discussion for the Web Accessibility Initiative and Repair Interest Group (WAI-ER-IG) which serves to advise the ER working group on methods of amending and improving websites.

Len then opens the discussion by introducing himself as a member of the Institute on Disabilities at Temple University with experience designing workstations for sighted people, people who read Braille and people who utilize large screens.
Daniel Dardailler responds next and tells the group he is the WAI Project Manager and the chair of the Evaluation and Repair Working Group, which receives recommendations from from WAI-ER-IG.
Daniel has been involved in web accessibility of several years and even helped to launch WAI in 1997; he believes that the work of this focus group is important in improving web access to all people.
Al Gilman is the next group member and introduces himself as the chair of the WAI Protocols and Formats Working Group and a member of the Trace Centre Team
Gregg Vanderheiden is from the University of Wisconsin where he works on accessibility and information technology
Phill Jenkins is from IBM Special Needs Systems where he works on many projects to enhance accessibility.
Finally, Kitch Barnicle works for the American Foundation of the Blind technology access program and is a graduate student in the area of including people with disabilities in assessing technology.
Simon shares his found with everyone about a website.
Jon asks where it is.
Tina Marie agrees with Simon about the website accessibility poll but can't get at the results either with Opera or Lynx, so she asks for an update to the list of data.
Simon explains where the poll is and reveals more problems about the website.
Rust responds to Tina's earlier request about an update.
Nissen quotes the website.
Jim asks some more questions about the website.
Simon gives more updates about the website and apologizes about the problems.
Simon White emailed a list of colleagues a link to a website accessibility poll.
Jon Hanna was unable to find the results.
Tina Marie Holmboe replied to say the poll was indeed interesting and requested that Simon keep the group updated with the rest of the results.
Simon provided  additional details about the location of the poll on the website.
Randal Rust was surprised to read that 47% of respondents to the poll don't know how to make their website accessible.
Tom Gilder was unable to view the poll.
Dan Nissen posted the interim results of the poll asking if the respondents' websites were accessible to the disabled.
Tom Gilder wondered about the reliability of the poll.
Jim Tobias asked how many people had voted in the poll.
Andrew Johns indicated that someone on the list had emailed the website to find out how many people had voted and was waiting for a response.
Simon White replied and it appears he is the one waiting for additional details from the website, which he will forward on to the rest of the group when he gets them in.
There are two main topics in this set of emails, the first is directions to a website holding a Website accessibility poll
The second is the poll itself.
Laura asks if anyone knows of screen readers that use aural style sheets.
Charles answers that Emacspeak does, as may a future project.
Danny asks if he can run it in Windows.
Others answer that he may be able to through pwwebspeak or Meadow.
Laura asks if anyone knows of screen readers that support aural style sheets.
Charles says that Emacspeak is such a one.
Danny asks if Emacspeak runs on Windows, using Cygwin.
David says pwwebspeak used to use them, referring to either Emacspeak or Windows or both.
Charles says there is a project to make Emacpspeak run under Windows in Japanese and English, but he cannot read Japanese.
He asks if anyone can help.
Masayasu gives a link to Voice Windows and Voice Meadow.
It is a multi-lingual text to speech system for Windows 98.
Bob asks for the URL for the project to make Emacspeak run under Windows in Japanese.
His Linux box can read and write the Japanese code.
Laura asks if there is a screen-reader or speaking browser capable of supporting aural style sheets.
Charles responds that 'Emacspeak' does and knows of another project that may make another one.
Danny asks Charles if 'Emacspeak' will run on Windows using cygwin.
David responds to Danny that 'pwwebspeak' used to use them.

Charles comments that there is a project to make 'Emacspeak' run under Windows in both Japanese and English, but Charles Japanese is not strong enough to read the webpages and asks if anyone can help.
Masayasu responds to Charles with some translations, a weblink and points out the the word 'MEADOW' is an acronym.
Bob asks what is the weblink to the Japanese page and says that even though his Japanese is rusty he can has his computer set up to read and write the code.
Joe says that he is helping to set-up a small computer lab to examine web usability issues and to narrow the options he is asking others' opinions on tools that should be tested.

Jamie recommends Netscape 3.x and 4.x, a version of MS Internet Explorer, a text browser such as Lynx, PwWebSpeak for the voice browser and maybe Opera, a general screen reader (such as Jaws), and use of tools such as bobby and HTML validators.
he also sends two URLs and suggests to ask disabled users do the testing.

Charles does not recommend IE/Netscape, but  suggests validating HTML with Bobby and looking at Lynx (as a browser), a screen reader (eg winvision, or jaws) as well as a proper audio browser like pwWebSpeak (possibly WebTV and a Macintosh version of things).
He thinks that the key is to learn where the problems arise so you can cut back the test/repair cycle.
Kynn informs that there's an emulator for WebTV that runs on Windows 95/* and Macintosh that you can download from developer.webtv.net.

Joe said he needed help assemble and populate a computer lab to examine web usability issues, since it's a large topic he wanted to narrow the options explored and hear people's opinion about the tools that should be used.
He requested people to share their opinions and preferences privately.
Jamie suggested using Netscape 3.x and 4.x, a version of MS Internet Explorer, a text browser, PwWebSpeak for the voice browser and possibly Opera.

He also suggested to consider the use of a general screen reader and tools such as bobby and HTML validators and commented that it might be sensible to have disabled users do the testing and then provided 2 links (http://www.eeicom.com/dcwebmasters/pwd/ http://www.geocities.com/SiliconValley/Grid/5447/access.html).
Charles said he'd skip IE/Netscape but validate the HTML and check with Bobby, read and reflect on the results, for browsers he'd look at Lynx, a screen reader and a proper audio browser.
He suggested if possible using WebTV and a Macintosh version.
Charles commented that the key is solving the problems by design rather than by repair.
Robert was asking for a good reference URLs for WebTV and sent a private e-mail to Joe about "EEI Communications" with a reference link (www.eeicom.com/dcwebmasters/pwd).
Kynn suggested an emulator for WebTV that runs on Windows 95/* and Macintosh that is possible to download from developer.webtv.net.
A brain storming session requesting help with assembling and populating a small computer lab to examine usability issues.
Private responses are preferred so as not to start a browser war
Several suggestions are made including using Netscape 3.x and 4.x etc.

thread.name: no RDF Core telcon this friday, 9Jan, right?

sent.#text: Dan would like to know whether his day off with family will conflict with an RDF Core telecon.
He explains that he will not be able to make it.
Brian points out that there are possible agenda items for a telecon.
He proposes the WG to meet/approve the proposed wording changes on the 16th.
Eric responds by saying that this issue was on last Monday's SW-CG agenda but time ran out before they were able to discuss this.
Dan consents to the WG to meet, and leaves much for Eric to do
Jeremy proposes a more conversative way to approach this issue
Jeremy and Brian will not take immediate action and appear to agree to see how things will turn out before doling out their opinions
Dan asks if there is an RDF telecon on Friday.
