He has not seen notice, so assumes there isn't any.
Brian wonders the same.
He discusses a few agenda items for a telecon.
He asks Dan if the WG should meet to discuss these items.
He asks if the 16th is soon enough.
He then asks Eric if the CG seeks input from the WG.
He says he will send a notification of a telecon for the 16th Jan.
Eric says the CG is seeking input from the WG.
The issue is not urgent but should be addressed eventually.
Dan says the WG should meet to discuss the wording changes.
He is unsure if the 16th is soon enough.
He asks Eric to decide that.
Jeremy says he prefers not to discuss postponed issues until present ones are solved.
He apologizes for being cautious.
Brian says that he was proposing suggestions to the CG of how to resolve these issues, not resolutions of the issues.
He asks if Jeremy can contribute to such a discussion.
Jeremy says he is unsure if a procedural only meeting can be had.
He says he will say nothing if uncomfortable.
He asks for silence to not be taken as assent, for it is not.
Connolly has some family event to attend to on Friday and would like to know if it conflicts with a telecon session.
He had not seen a notice in 7 days and assumes there is no telecon this week.  Mcbribe is wondering whether there is a telecon meeting this week as well.
If there is one, he  recommends a. wording changes and b. advice to CG about postponed issues and wonders if Jan 16th is enough time.
He asks if people would like to meet to discuss a and b and if the CG is seeking information about the WG.
Miller responds and says yes the CG did seek information about the WG last week but they ran out of time to talk about it and it is not urgent.
Conolly says yes to Mcbribe's request for a meeting and wonders if the 16th is sufficient but doesn't have the a calender and will let Miller sort it out.
Carroll would prefer not to talk about postponed issues.
Mcbride responds that he was unclear in his last post and he does not want to discuss resolution of issues but rather suggestions to the CG.
Carrol is not sure if a procedural only discussion is viable and will stay silent if he's uncomfortable.

thread.name: General Rule - Do not forbid - only guide except for safety

sent.#text: Gregg said that guidelines shouldn't forbid anything but rather tell people how to behave and look through the next version.
Kynn supported Gregg and explained why.
Jason thought that WCAG 1.0 was consistent with the method but said that WCAG 2.0 should make the point even clearer.
Anne supported Gregg as well and commented that some disabled group might need somtthing that was forbidden.
Kynn agreed with Ann and referred to building interfaces for different audiences, he also commented that absolutes should be avoided and William agreed.
Gregg proposes that the guidelines they design should not forbid anything and they should check the next  version that comes out next week to see whether it forbids anything.
Anne and William agree with his point.
Kynn agrees with the approach and he thinks although the guidelines should not forbid anything but should provide consequences of each action.

Jason thinks that even WCAG 1.0, the current version, does not forbid any action; however, the new version, WCAG 2.0, should make it clearer, to avoid giving the impression that there are prohibitions in the guidelines that would limit the capacity of content creators to design web sites.
A member is expressing his opinion that guidelines should be designed to not forbid any action, but rather should take accessibility into consideration.
He would like to take this approach when reviewing the next version which is due out shortly.

Another member completely agrees with this approach, stating that guidelines should guide and not forbid, making it known that there is a choice but some choices are better than others and all have consequences.
Another member comments that the first version also takes this approach by using the word "avoid", but that it could be stated even more clearly in the next version.
Another member also agrees and makes the point that what has been forbidden might be "necessary" to some and that authors need to be aware of consequences and what is best for their individual sites.
Yet another member also completely agrees and states that absolutes should always be avoided.
A final member responds and completely agrees with the last poster's comments.
Jesper asks whether some disabled users prefer white-on-black text over black-on-white text.
John answers that they sometimes do, and he knows two that have set up their computers to use white-on-black.
Sandra mentions that some users swap between the two settings as their eyes tire.
Matthew asks whether other colours could be used, and mentions a study that may show that other colours may be helpful.
Jesper muses whether computer users, disabled or not, would prefer to have white text on black background than the opposite.
If so, he will include both options in a style switcher he is making.
John replies that many visually impaired users do prefer white text on black.
This is partially because the glare from a white screen is hard on the eyes.
Bob, the Access Systems manager, says he will only use the internet and other programs with white on black.
Sandra says that some people swap between the two styles as they desire.
She adds that Jesper should not prevent people from using their own style preferences.
Matthew asks whether Jesper will include other colour schemes.
David says the the reason for using white on black is because flicker is more distinct on areas of white.
On CRT monitors, some fonts don't handle white on black well.
Jesper asks if users find text easier to read when it is white on a black background or vice versa and if so he would include both in the style switcher he is making.
John responds and says that most people with visual impairment prefer the light on dark background because of the reduction in glare from the screen.
bob comments that he only reads things on the internet when it is set white on black.
Sandra makes the point that she knows people swap between black on white and vice versa depending on their needs and recommends that any style switcher be flexible.
Matthew asks if Jesper will be including other color schemes and cites a few example color schemes, some of which are better for those with dyslexia.
David comments that he thought that for using white on black is to make flicker less obvious and explains why.
